Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. ğŸš€ğŸ”” Follow me to get these updates!ğŸ’¬ Which Java trick interests you most? Fiverr or Upwork?The proactiveness in building a strong reputation, delivering quality work and engaging with these platforms are key drivers for achieving consistency but these are some factors influencing these consistency most new freelancers are not aware of:1. Reputation and Reviews: Both platforms rely heavily on feedback and ratings. Consistent positive reviews lead to more visibility and client trust, fostering a steady stream of work.2. Profile Optimization: Continuously updating a well-crafted profile showcasing skills, experience, and clear service offerings helps freelancers attract relevant clients consistently.3. Responsiveness and Communication: Prompt and professional communication is crucial for building client relationships and securing repeat business. Inconsistent communication can lead to lost opportunities.4. Service Quality and Reliability: Delivering high-quality work on time is fundamental for maintaining consistency. Inconsistencies in quality can lead to negative feedback and fewer job offers.5. Pricing Strategy: Competitive and fair pricing, aligned with the freelancer's skill level and market rates, can contribute to a consistent flow of projects. 6. Securing Long-Term Projects: While Upwork facilitates longer engagements, consistently finding and securing these can still be a challenge.As a freelancer, how consistent are you on fiverr and Upwork?hashtag#freelancingplatforms hashtag#freelancerthoughts hashtag#consistency

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Here is a small useful Rendering Tool I recently worked which makes it easy to Render image sequence in hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana projectKey Features are:1.Render multiple/infinite Render nodes sequentially. you give it all the render nodes in your .katana project file and their frame range, the it will batch render the next render node after the first is finished until all nodes finish rendering. eg: node2 after node1, node3 after node2, node4 after node3 etc, unlimited.2.Render engine independent, works with any Render Engine supported by Katana.3.Katana version independent. works with any katana version, older or newer.4. Threaded Execution (No Freezing UI), tool runs in separate thread to from freezing when rendering5. Render log file for each render node.- Each render node generates a log file in the project directory.- The log file is named: RenderNode_Render_Log_TIMESTAMP.txt- It captures all rendering activity, errors, and messages.6. Shutdown After Render (Checkbox) If enabled shutdown in 60 secs after the last render node finishes rendering. 7. Supports Windows and LinuxNB: Katana Batch Master works on a single workstation.https://lnkd.in/dnySa8fPhashtag#Lightingartist hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana8.0 hashtag#Rendering hashtag#Renderman hashtag#USD hashtag#Lookdev hashtag#PipelineTD hashtag#Render

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. ğŸš€ğŸ”” Follow me to get these updates!ğŸ’¬ Which Java trick interests you most? Fiverr or Upwork?The proactiveness in building a strong reputation, delivering quality work and engaging with these platforms are key drivers for achieving consistency but these are some factors influencing these consistency most new freelancers are not aware of:1. Reputation and Reviews: Both platforms rely heavily on feedback and ratings. Consistent positive reviews lead to more visibility and client trust, fostering a steady stream of work.2. Profile Optimization: Continuously updating a well-crafted profile showcasing skills, experience, and clear service offerings helps freelancers attract relevant clients consistently.3. Responsiveness and Communication: Prompt and professional communication is crucial for building client relationships and securing repeat business. Inconsistent communication can lead to lost opportunities.4. Service Quality and Reliability: Delivering high-quality work on time is fundamental for maintaining consistency. Inconsistencies in quality can lead to negative feedback and fewer job offers.5. Pricing Strategy: Competitive and fair pricing, aligned with the freelancer's skill level and market rates, can contribute to a consistent flow of projects. 6. Securing Long-Term Projects: While Upwork facilitates longer engagements, consistently finding and securing these can still be a challenge.As a freelancer, how consistent are you on fiverr and Upwork?hashtag#freelancingplatforms hashtag#freelancerthoughts hashtag#consistency

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Here is a small useful Rendering Tool I recently worked which makes it easy to Render image sequence in hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana projectKey Features are:1.Render multiple/infinite Render nodes sequentially. you give it all the render nodes in your .katana project file and their frame range, the it will batch render the next render node after the first is finished until all nodes finish rendering. eg: node2 after node1, node3 after node2, node4 after node3 etc, unlimited.2.Render engine independent, works with any Render Engine supported by Katana.3.Katana version independent. works with any katana version, older or newer.4. Threaded Execution (No Freezing UI), tool runs in separate thread to from freezing when rendering5. Render log file for each render node.- Each render node generates a log file in the project directory.- The log file is named: RenderNode_Render_Log_TIMESTAMP.txt- It captures all rendering activity, errors, and messages.6. Shutdown After Render (Checkbox) If enabled shutdown in 60 secs after the last render node finishes rendering. 7. Supports Windows and LinuxNB: Katana Batch Master works on a single workstation.https://lnkd.in/dnySa8fPhashtag#Lightingartist hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana8.0 hashtag#Rendering hashtag#Renderman hashtag#USD hashtag#Lookdev hashtag#PipelineTD hashtag#Render

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 58/100 â€“ Method Overriding & Runtime Polymorphism in JavaToday I explored Method Overriding â€” a key feature of runtime polymorphism in Java!In this example:A parent1 class has a method show()A child0 class overrides the same methodAt runtime, the childâ€™s method is executed, even though the reference is of the parent type!Code Output:javaCopy codeparent1 p = new child0();p.show();  // Output: "child class method"Why this matters:Enables dynamic method dispatchPromotes loose couplingMakes Java truly object-orientedLesson of the Day:Itâ€™s not about the reference, itâ€™s about the object behind it!hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#OOP hashtag#Polymorphism hashtag#MethodOverriding hashtag#RuntimeMagic hashtag#CodeBetter hashtag#Jainuniversity Dr Sagar Gulati Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A â˜•ï¸ğŸ’¡ğŸ”ğŸ§ âœ¨

ğŸ”§ Weekly Embedded Systems Challenge: "Smart Mailbox Notifier"ğŸ“¨ Main Challenge:Build a Smart Mailbox Notifier that detects when new mail is delivered and sends a notification (e.g., via LED, sound, or wireless message).ğŸ› ï¸ Core Requirements:Use a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino, ESP32, STM32, etc.).Include a sensor to detect the mailbox opening (magnetic reed switch, IR, ultrasonic, or light sensor).Use an output method to notify (LED, buzzer, or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth alert to phone).Ensure the system is battery-powered and low power, waking only on trigger.â­ Extra Credit (Advanced Tasks):Wireless Notification: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to send a push notification or email when mail arrives.Battery Optimization: Implement deep sleep and power-saving strategies.Data Logging: Log timestamps of deliveries to local memory (SD card) or cloud.Tamper Detection: Add a secondary sensor to detect tampering or theft.Weatherproofing: Design a 3D-printed or rugged enclosure for outdoor deployment.ğŸ“¸ Share Your Work:Post a photo/video of your Smart Mailbox in action.Share your schematic, code, and power optimization tricks.Bonus: Create a GitHub repo or Instructable to document your build!ğŸ’¬ Community Discussion Starters:What other household objects could benefit from embedded automation?What are your favorite low-power microcontrollers or sleep strategies?How would you expand this into a smart home ecosystem?

ğŸŸ¢ğŸŸ What Is Commitizen â€” And Why Developers Should Stop Ignoring ItIn software teams, your Git history is either a goldmine â€” or chaos.So how do we make commits consistent, readable, and CI-friendly?Today Iâ€™ll explain what Commitizen is â€” and why it just saved my sanity.1) Why Youâ€™d Want ThisTo make commit messages:Consistent across teams & contributorsParseable by release tools like semantic-releaseAuto-generate changelogsCI/CD friendlyEnforce feat, fix, docs style formatting.2) What Is Commitizen?Commitizen is a developer-friendly CLI tool to write standardized Git commit messages.It prompts you with:Type (feat, fix, chore...)Scope (optional)Short and long descriptionsNo more free-text chaos. Just structure and clarity.3) What Makes It PowerfulWorks with any Git-based repoUses adapters like cz-conventional-changelogCompatible with semantic-releaseEasy to set up in new projectsCan be reused across all future repos.4) My Debug JourneyStarted with npx cz failing silentlyLearned how Commitizen uses internal adaptersFixed the config manually in package.jsonCreated a reusable boilerplate projectğŸŸ¡ğŸŸ Now it works with just one line in any new repo:npx commitizen init cz-conventional-changelog --save-dev --save-exact5) Things to Watch Out ForDonâ€™t install globally â€” use local node_modulesAdapter path must match correctlyUse --force if reinitializingIf .lock file errors happen, delete them manually (.git/index.lock, package-lock.json)6) Why It MattersCommitizen enforces clean, readable Git history. It makes collaboration easier. It helps automate changelogs and releases. It brings discipline without slowing you down.Follow Kisalay Srivastava for deep-dive Git tools, debugging wins, and dev workflows that actually scale.ğŸ”"Your commit messages tell your story â€” letâ€™s make them worth reading."hashtag#Commitizen hashtag#Git hashtag#DevTools hashtag#DeveloperExperience hashtag#SemanticRelease hashtag#CommitMessage hashtag#Changelogs hashtag#DeveloperTools hashtag#Kisalay hashtag#NodeJSNodeJS Developer Node.js

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. ğŸš€ğŸ”” Follow me to get these updates!ğŸ’¬ Which Java trick interests you most? Fiverr or Upwork?The proactiveness in building a strong reputation, delivering quality work and engaging with these platforms are key drivers for achieving consistency but these are some factors influencing these consistency most new freelancers are not aware of:1. Reputation and Reviews: Both platforms rely heavily on feedback and ratings. Consistent positive reviews lead to more visibility and client trust, fostering a steady stream of work.2. Profile Optimization: Continuously updating a well-crafted profile showcasing skills, experience, and clear service offerings helps freelancers attract relevant clients consistently.3. Responsiveness and Communication: Prompt and professional communication is crucial for building client relationships and securing repeat business. Inconsistent communication can lead to lost opportunities.4. Service Quality and Reliability: Delivering high-quality work on time is fundamental for maintaining consistency. Inconsistencies in quality can lead to negative feedback and fewer job offers.5. Pricing Strategy: Competitive and fair pricing, aligned with the freelancer's skill level and market rates, can contribute to a consistent flow of projects. 6. Securing Long-Term Projects: While Upwork facilitates longer engagements, consistently finding and securing these can still be a challenge.As a freelancer, how consistent are you on fiverr and Upwork?hashtag#freelancingplatforms hashtag#freelancerthoughts hashtag#consistency

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Here is a small useful Rendering Tool I recently worked which makes it easy to Render image sequence in hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana projectKey Features are:1.Render multiple/infinite Render nodes sequentially. you give it all the render nodes in your .katana project file and their frame range, the it will batch render the next render node after the first is finished until all nodes finish rendering. eg: node2 after node1, node3 after node2, node4 after node3 etc, unlimited.2.Render engine independent, works with any Render Engine supported by Katana.3.Katana version independent. works with any katana version, older or newer.4. Threaded Execution (No Freezing UI), tool runs in separate thread to from freezing when rendering5. Render log file for each render node.- Each render node generates a log file in the project directory.- The log file is named: RenderNode_Render_Log_TIMESTAMP.txt- It captures all rendering activity, errors, and messages.6. Shutdown After Render (Checkbox) If enabled shutdown in 60 secs after the last render node finishes rendering. 7. Supports Windows and LinuxNB: Katana Batch Master works on a single workstation.https://lnkd.in/dnySa8fPhashtag#Lightingartist hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana8.0 hashtag#Rendering hashtag#Renderman hashtag#USD hashtag#Lookdev hashtag#PipelineTD hashtag#Render

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 58/100 â€“ Method Overriding & Runtime Polymorphism in JavaToday I explored Method Overriding â€” a key feature of runtime polymorphism in Java!In this example:A parent1 class has a method show()A child0 class overrides the same methodAt runtime, the childâ€™s method is executed, even though the reference is of the parent type!Code Output:javaCopy codeparent1 p = new child0();p.show();  // Output: "child class method"Why this matters:Enables dynamic method dispatchPromotes loose couplingMakes Java truly object-orientedLesson of the Day:Itâ€™s not about the reference, itâ€™s about the object behind it!hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#OOP hashtag#Polymorphism hashtag#MethodOverriding hashtag#RuntimeMagic hashtag#CodeBetter hashtag#Jainuniversity Dr Sagar Gulati Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A â˜•ï¸ğŸ’¡ğŸ”ğŸ§ âœ¨

ğŸ”§ Weekly Embedded Systems Challenge: "Smart Mailbox Notifier"ğŸ“¨ Main Challenge:Build a Smart Mailbox Notifier that detects when new mail is delivered and sends a notification (e.g., via LED, sound, or wireless message).ğŸ› ï¸ Core Requirements:Use a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino, ESP32, STM32, etc.).Include a sensor to detect the mailbox opening (magnetic reed switch, IR, ultrasonic, or light sensor).Use an output method to notify (LED, buzzer, or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth alert to phone).Ensure the system is battery-powered and low power, waking only on trigger.â­ Extra Credit (Advanced Tasks):Wireless Notification: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to send a push notification or email when mail arrives.Battery Optimization: Implement deep sleep and power-saving strategies.Data Logging: Log timestamps of deliveries to local memory (SD card) or cloud.Tamper Detection: Add a secondary sensor to detect tampering or theft.Weatherproofing: Design a 3D-printed or rugged enclosure for outdoor deployment.ğŸ“¸ Share Your Work:Post a photo/video of your Smart Mailbox in action.Share your schematic, code, and power optimization tricks.Bonus: Create a GitHub repo or Instructable to document your build!ğŸ’¬ Community Discussion Starters:What other household objects could benefit from embedded automation?What are your favorite low-power microcontrollers or sleep strategies?How would you expand this into a smart home ecosystem?

GFG Weekly - 208 Contest âœ¨ | GFG really needs to fix the IDEToday I gave a contest on GeeksforGeeks and achieved a a rank 42 out of ~900 participants. Although the questions were fine, I experienced many problems related to the environment.I strongly recommend GeeksforGeeks to fix the IDE and the UX used in the contests, as It had many bugs, incredibly slow compile time and almost zero flexibility over running custom testcases. Plus there is this bug where I changed my theme to dark, and the code I wrote literally changed to a previously written version, meaning a part of my code vanished just because I changed the theme. Additionally, running custom testcases is a total nightmare in the IDE given, not interative at all.I mostly participate in the contests hosted on LeetCode. Coming from that platform, GeeksforGeeks you really need to fix the UX and the bugs and Improve the overall experience. After giving the GFG contest today I dont think I will ever compete here again (which explains <1000 participants).hashtag#geeksforgeeks

ğŸŸ¢ğŸŸ What Is Commitizen â€” And Why Developers Should Stop Ignoring ItIn software teams, your Git history is either a goldmine â€” or chaos.So how do we make commits consistent, readable, and CI-friendly?Today Iâ€™ll explain what Commitizen is â€” and why it just saved my sanity.1) Why Youâ€™d Want ThisTo make commit messages:Consistent across teams & contributorsParseable by release tools like semantic-releaseAuto-generate changelogsCI/CD friendlyEnforce feat, fix, docs style formatting.2) What Is Commitizen?Commitizen is a developer-friendly CLI tool to write standardized Git commit messages.It prompts you with:Type (feat, fix, chore...)Scope (optional)Short and long descriptionsNo more free-text chaos. Just structure and clarity.3) What Makes It PowerfulWorks with any Git-based repoUses adapters like cz-conventional-changelogCompatible with semantic-releaseEasy to set up in new projectsCan be reused across all future repos.4) My Debug JourneyStarted with npx cz failing silentlyLearned how Commitizen uses internal adaptersFixed the config manually in package.jsonCreated a reusable boilerplate projectğŸŸ¡ğŸŸ Now it works with just one line in any new repo:npx commitizen init cz-conventional-changelog --save-dev --save-exact5) Things to Watch Out ForDonâ€™t install globally â€” use local node_modulesAdapter path must match correctlyUse --force if reinitializingIf .lock file errors happen, delete them manually (.git/index.lock, package-lock.json)6) Why It MattersCommitizen enforces clean, readable Git history. It makes collaboration easier. It helps automate changelogs and releases. It brings discipline without slowing you down.Follow Kisalay Srivastava for deep-dive Git tools, debugging wins, and dev workflows that actually scale.ğŸ”"Your commit messages tell your story â€” letâ€™s make them worth reading."hashtag#Commitizen hashtag#Git hashtag#DevTools hashtag#DeveloperExperience hashtag#SemanticRelease hashtag#CommitMessage hashtag#Changelogs hashtag#DeveloperTools hashtag#Kisalay hashtag#NodeJSNodeJS Developer Node.js

Day 56/100 â€“ Method Overloading with Multiple Classes challenge, designed to be engaging and professional with emoji flair:Today I implemented Method Overloading using two real-world inspired classes:Course and Fees â€” because even code needs a syllabus and a fee structure!Whatâ€™s inside:courseDetails() overloaded to display course name and course durationfeeDetail() overloaded to show fees and payment typeLearning Highlights:Same method name, different parameters = Method OverloadingBoosts flexibility & keeps code intuitiveGreat for real-life applications like college portals, course management systems, etc.Code Sneak Peek:course.courseDetails("Java Programming");course.courseDetails("Java Programming", 6);fees.feeDetail(200);fees.feeDetail(200, "Full Payment");From classrooms to code â€” everything can be modular!hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#OOPs hashtag#MethodOverloading hashtag#LearnToCode hashtag#RealWorldCoding hashtag#CodeSmart hashtag#jainuniversityDr Sagar Gulati Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A â˜•ï¸ğŸ“˜ğŸ’»ğŸ¯ğŸ“š

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. ğŸš€ğŸ”” Follow me to get these updates!ğŸ’¬ Which Java trick interests you most? Fiverr or Upwork?The proactiveness in building a strong reputation, delivering quality work and engaging with these platforms are key drivers for achieving consistency but these are some factors influencing these consistency most new freelancers are not aware of:1. Reputation and Reviews: Both platforms rely heavily on feedback and ratings. Consistent positive reviews lead to more visibility and client trust, fostering a steady stream of work.2. Profile Optimization: Continuously updating a well-crafted profile showcasing skills, experience, and clear service offerings helps freelancers attract relevant clients consistently.3. Responsiveness and Communication: Prompt and professional communication is crucial for building client relationships and securing repeat business. Inconsistent communication can lead to lost opportunities.4. Service Quality and Reliability: Delivering high-quality work on time is fundamental for maintaining consistency. Inconsistencies in quality can lead to negative feedback and fewer job offers.5. Pricing Strategy: Competitive and fair pricing, aligned with the freelancer's skill level and market rates, can contribute to a consistent flow of projects. 6. Securing Long-Term Projects: While Upwork facilitates longer engagements, consistently finding and securing these can still be a challenge.As a freelancer, how consistent are you on fiverr and Upwork?hashtag#freelancingplatforms hashtag#freelancerthoughts hashtag#consistency

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Here is a small useful Rendering Tool I recently worked which makes it easy to Render image sequence in hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana projectKey Features are:1.Render multiple/infinite Render nodes sequentially. you give it all the render nodes in your .katana project file and their frame range, the it will batch render the next render node after the first is finished until all nodes finish rendering. eg: node2 after node1, node3 after node2, node4 after node3 etc, unlimited.2.Render engine independent, works with any Render Engine supported by Katana.3.Katana version independent. works with any katana version, older or newer.4. Threaded Execution (No Freezing UI), tool runs in separate thread to from freezing when rendering5. Render log file for each render node.- Each render node generates a log file in the project directory.- The log file is named: RenderNode_Render_Log_TIMESTAMP.txt- It captures all rendering activity, errors, and messages.6. Shutdown After Render (Checkbox) If enabled shutdown in 60 secs after the last render node finishes rendering. 7. Supports Windows and LinuxNB: Katana Batch Master works on a single workstation.https://lnkd.in/dnySa8fPhashtag#Lightingartist hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana8.0 hashtag#Rendering hashtag#Renderman hashtag#USD hashtag#Lookdev hashtag#PipelineTD hashtag#Render

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 58/100 â€“ Method Overriding & Runtime Polymorphism in JavaToday I explored Method Overriding â€” a key feature of runtime polymorphism in Java!In this example:A parent1 class has a method show()A child0 class overrides the same methodAt runtime, the childâ€™s method is executed, even though the reference is of the parent type!Code Output:javaCopy codeparent1 p = new child0();p.show();  // Output: "child class method"Why this matters:Enables dynamic method dispatchPromotes loose couplingMakes Java truly object-orientedLesson of the Day:Itâ€™s not about the reference, itâ€™s about the object behind it!hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#OOP hashtag#Polymorphism hashtag#MethodOverriding hashtag#RuntimeMagic hashtag#CodeBetter hashtag#Jainuniversity Dr Sagar Gulati Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A â˜•ï¸ğŸ’¡ğŸ”ğŸ§ âœ¨

ğŸ”§ Weekly Embedded Systems Challenge: "Smart Mailbox Notifier"ğŸ“¨ Main Challenge:Build a Smart Mailbox Notifier that detects when new mail is delivered and sends a notification (e.g., via LED, sound, or wireless message).ğŸ› ï¸ Core Requirements:Use a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino, ESP32, STM32, etc.).Include a sensor to detect the mailbox opening (magnetic reed switch, IR, ultrasonic, or light sensor).Use an output method to notify (LED, buzzer, or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth alert to phone).Ensure the system is battery-powered and low power, waking only on trigger.â­ Extra Credit (Advanced Tasks):Wireless Notification: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to send a push notification or email when mail arrives.Battery Optimization: Implement deep sleep and power-saving strategies.Data Logging: Log timestamps of deliveries to local memory (SD card) or cloud.Tamper Detection: Add a secondary sensor to detect tampering or theft.Weatherproofing: Design a 3D-printed or rugged enclosure for outdoor deployment.ğŸ“¸ Share Your Work:Post a photo/video of your Smart Mailbox in action.Share your schematic, code, and power optimization tricks.Bonus: Create a GitHub repo or Instructable to document your build!ğŸ’¬ Community Discussion Starters:What other household objects could benefit from embedded automation?What are your favorite low-power microcontrollers or sleep strategies?How would you expand this into a smart home ecosystem?

ğŸŸ¢ğŸŸ What Is Commitizen â€” And Why Developers Should Stop Ignoring ItIn software teams, your Git history is either a goldmine â€” or chaos.So how do we make commits consistent, readable, and CI-friendly?Today Iâ€™ll explain what Commitizen is â€” and why it just saved my sanity.1) Why Youâ€™d Want ThisTo make commit messages:Consistent across teams & contributorsParseable by release tools like semantic-releaseAuto-generate changelogsCI/CD friendlyEnforce feat, fix, docs style formatting.2) What Is Commitizen?Commitizen is a developer-friendly CLI tool to write standardized Git commit messages.It prompts you with:Type (feat, fix, chore...)Scope (optional)Short and long descriptionsNo more free-text chaos. Just structure and clarity.3) What Makes It PowerfulWorks with any Git-based repoUses adapters like cz-conventional-changelogCompatible with semantic-releaseEasy to set up in new projectsCan be reused across all future repos.4) My Debug JourneyStarted with npx cz failing silentlyLearned how Commitizen uses internal adaptersFixed the config manually in package.jsonCreated a reusable boilerplate projectğŸŸ¡ğŸŸ Now it works with just one line in any new repo:npx commitizen init cz-conventional-changelog --save-dev --save-exact5) Things to Watch Out ForDonâ€™t install globally â€” use local node_modulesAdapter path must match correctlyUse --force if reinitializingIf .lock file errors happen, delete them manually (.git/index.lock, package-lock.json)6) Why It MattersCommitizen enforces clean, readable Git history. It makes collaboration easier. It helps automate changelogs and releases. It brings discipline without slowing you down.Follow Kisalay Srivastava for deep-dive Git tools, debugging wins, and dev workflows that actually scale.ğŸ”"Your commit messages tell your story â€” letâ€™s make them worth reading."hashtag#Commitizen hashtag#Git hashtag#DevTools hashtag#DeveloperExperience hashtag#SemanticRelease hashtag#CommitMessage hashtag#Changelogs hashtag#DeveloperTools hashtag#Kisalay hashtag#NodeJSNodeJS Developer Node.js

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Fiverr or Upwork?The proactiveness in building a strong reputation, delivering quality work and engaging with these platforms are key drivers for achieving consistency but these are some factors influencing these consistency most new freelancers are not aware of:1. Reputation and Reviews: Both platforms rely heavily on feedback and ratings. Consistent positive reviews lead to more visibility and client trust, fostering a steady stream of work.2. Profile Optimization: Continuously updating a well-crafted profile showcasing skills, experience, and clear service offerings helps freelancers attract relevant clients consistently.3. Responsiveness and Communication: Prompt and professional communication is crucial for building client relationships and securing repeat business. Inconsistent communication can lead to lost opportunities.4. Service Quality and Reliability: Delivering high-quality work on time is fundamental for maintaining consistency. Inconsistencies in quality can lead to negative feedback and fewer job offers.5. Pricing Strategy: Competitive and fair pricing, aligned with the freelancer's skill level and market rates, can contribute to a consistent flow of projects. 6. Securing Long-Term Projects: While Upwork facilitates longer engagements, consistently finding and securing these can still be a challenge.As a freelancer, how consistent are you on fiverr and Upwork?hashtag#freelancingplatforms hashtag#freelancerthoughts hashtag#consistency

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Here is a small useful Rendering Tool I recently worked which makes it easy to Render image sequence in hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana projectKey Features are:1.Render multiple/infinite Render nodes sequentially. you give it all the render nodes in your .katana project file and their frame range, the it will batch render the next render node after the first is finished until all nodes finish rendering. eg: node2 after node1, node3 after node2, node4 after node3 etc, unlimited.2.Render engine independent, works with any Render Engine supported by Katana.3.Katana version independent. works with any katana version, older or newer.4. Threaded Execution (No Freezing UI), tool runs in separate thread to from freezing when rendering5. Render log file for each render node.- Each render node generates a log file in the project directory.- The log file is named: RenderNode_Render_Log_TIMESTAMP.txt- It captures all rendering activity, errors, and messages.6. Shutdown After Render (Checkbox) If enabled shutdown in 60 secs after the last render node finishes rendering. 7. Supports Windows and LinuxNB: Katana Batch Master works on a single workstation.https://lnkd.in/dnySa8fPhashtag#Lightingartist hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana8.0 hashtag#Rendering hashtag#Renderman hashtag#USD hashtag#Lookdev hashtag#PipelineTD hashtag#Render

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 58/100 â€“ Method Overriding & Runtime Polymorphism in JavaToday I explored Method Overriding â€” a key feature of runtime polymorphism in Java!In this example:A parent1 class has a method show()A child0 class overrides the same methodAt runtime, the childâ€™s method is executed, even though the reference is of the parent type!Code Output:javaCopy codeparent1 p = new child0();p.show();  // Output: "child class method"Why this matters:Enables dynamic method dispatchPromotes loose couplingMakes Java truly object-orientedLesson of the Day:Itâ€™s not about the reference, itâ€™s about the object behind it!hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#OOP hashtag#Polymorphism hashtag#MethodOverriding hashtag#RuntimeMagic hashtag#CodeBetter hashtag#Jainuniversity Dr Sagar Gulati Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A â˜•ï¸ğŸ’¡ğŸ”ğŸ§ âœ¨

ğŸ”§ Weekly Embedded Systems Challenge: "Smart Mailbox Notifier"ğŸ“¨ Main Challenge:Build a Smart Mailbox Notifier that detects when new mail is delivered and sends a notification (e.g., via LED, sound, or wireless message).ğŸ› ï¸ Core Requirements:Use a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino, ESP32, STM32, etc.).Include a sensor to detect the mailbox opening (magnetic reed switch, IR, ultrasonic, or light sensor).Use an output method to notify (LED, buzzer, or Wi-Fi/Bluetooth alert to phone).Ensure the system is battery-powered and low power, waking only on trigger.â­ Extra Credit (Advanced Tasks):Wireless Notification: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth to send a push notification or email when mail arrives.Battery Optimization: Implement deep sleep and power-saving strategies.Data Logging: Log timestamps of deliveries to local memory (SD card) or cloud.Tamper Detection: Add a secondary sensor to detect tampering or theft.Weatherproofing: Design a 3D-printed or rugged enclosure for outdoor deployment.ğŸ“¸ Share Your Work:Post a photo/video of your Smart Mailbox in action.Share your schematic, code, and power optimization tricks.Bonus: Create a GitHub repo or Instructable to document your build!ğŸ’¬ Community Discussion Starters:What other household objects could benefit from embedded automation?What are your favorite low-power microcontrollers or sleep strategies?How would you expand this into a smart home ecosystem?

ğŸŸ¢ğŸŸ What Is Commitizen â€” And Why Developers Should Stop Ignoring ItIn software teams, your Git history is either a goldmine â€” or chaos.So how do we make commits consistent, readable, and CI-friendly?Today Iâ€™ll explain what Commitizen is â€” and why it just saved my sanity.1) Why Youâ€™d Want ThisTo make commit messages:Consistent across teams & contributorsParseable by release tools like semantic-releaseAuto-generate changelogsCI/CD friendlyEnforce feat, fix, docs style formatting.2) What Is Commitizen?Commitizen is a developer-friendly CLI tool to write standardized Git commit messages.It prompts you with:Type (feat, fix, chore...)Scope (optional)Short and long descriptionsNo more free-text chaos. Just structure and clarity.3) What Makes It PowerfulWorks with any Git-based repoUses adapters like cz-conventional-changelogCompatible with semantic-releaseEasy to set up in new projectsCan be reused across all future repos.4) My Debug JourneyStarted with npx cz failing silentlyLearned how Commitizen uses internal adaptersFixed the config manually in package.jsonCreated a reusable boilerplate projectğŸŸ¡ğŸŸ Now it works with just one line in any new repo:npx commitizen init cz-conventional-changelog --save-dev --save-exact5) Things to Watch Out ForDonâ€™t install globally â€” use local node_modulesAdapter path must match correctlyUse --force if reinitializingIf .lock file errors happen, delete them manually (.git/index.lock, package-lock.json)6) Why It MattersCommitizen enforces clean, readable Git history. It makes collaboration easier. It helps automate changelogs and releases. It brings discipline without slowing you down.Follow Kisalay Srivastava for deep-dive Git tools, debugging wins, and dev workflows that actually scale.ğŸ”"Your commit messages tell your story â€” letâ€™s make them worth reading."hashtag#Commitizen hashtag#Git hashtag#DevTools hashtag#DeveloperExperience hashtag#SemanticRelease hashtag#CommitMessage hashtag#Changelogs hashtag#DeveloperTools hashtag#Kisalay hashtag#NodeJSNodeJS Developer Node.js

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. ğŸš€ğŸ”” Follow me to get these updates!ğŸ’¬ Which Java trick interests you most? Fiverr or Upwork?The proactiveness in building a strong reputation, delivering quality work and engaging with these platforms are key drivers for achieving consistency but these are some factors influencing these consistency most new freelancers are not aware of:1. Reputation and Reviews: Both platforms rely heavily on feedback and ratings. Consistent positive reviews lead to more visibility and client trust, fostering a steady stream of work.2. Profile Optimization: Continuously updating a well-crafted profile showcasing skills, experience, and clear service offerings helps freelancers attract relevant clients consistently.3. Responsiveness and Communication: Prompt and professional communication is crucial for building client relationships and securing repeat business. Inconsistent communication can lead to lost opportunities.4. Service Quality and Reliability: Delivering high-quality work on time is fundamental for maintaining consistency. Inconsistencies in quality can lead to negative feedback and fewer job offers.5. Pricing Strategy: Competitive and fair pricing, aligned with the freelancer's skill level and market rates, can contribute to a consistent flow of projects. 6. Securing Long-Term Projects: While Upwork facilitates longer engagements, consistently finding and securing these can still be a challenge.As a freelancer, how consistent are you on fiverr and Upwork?hashtag#freelancingplatforms hashtag#freelancerthoughts hashtag#consistency

When NVS Fails on ESP32â€¦ LittleFS to the Rescue! In one of our recent IoT projects, we ran into a tricky issue after rolling out a new firmware update (OTA) to all our ESP32-based devices. Out of nearly 30,000 units, about 100 started acting weirdâ€”some configs didnâ€™t load properly, and things just didnâ€™t add up.After digging into it, we found the root cause: we had increased the EEPROM size from 2KB to 5KB, and it turned out NVS couldnâ€™t handle it well on all devices.When we scanned the full memory, we saw corruption issues in those affected devices. ğŸ˜¬So, together with my teammates, we decided to shift our strategy.We moved our data and device configurations from NVS to SPIFFS using LittleFS ---> and it worked like a charm! ğŸ‹  Everything became stable and clean again.ğŸ” A quick takeaway:Sometimes NVS isn't the best fit for larger or dynamic data. LittleFS gave us the reliability we needed for this scale of deployment.Just wanted to share in case someone else is hitting a similar wallâ€”hope it saves you some time!hashtag#ESP32 hashtag#IoT hashtag#LittleFS hashtag#NVS hashtag#SPIFFS hashtag#FirmwareUpdate hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#MemoryManagement hashtag#TechFix

"ÙˆÙÙ‚ÙÙ„ Ø±ÙÙ‘Ø¨ÙÙ‘ Ø²ÙØ¯Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠ Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù’Ù…Ù‹Ø§" â€“ Ø³ÙˆØ±Ø© Ø·Ù‡ØŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¢ÙŠØ© 114ğŸ”§ MCSA Project 5: Deploying a Multi-Site Domain Controller with IFM and NIC Teaming â€“ A Real-World SimulationIâ€™ve just completed my fifth and most comprehensive MCSA project so far â€” a full-scale enterprise-level deployment involving multiple sites, advanced domain replication, and optimized server communication. Here's a breakdown of what I implemented:1ï¸âƒ£ Creating IFM Media for Domain Replication To simulate a real-world "Install From Media" (IFM) scenario, I generated a custom IFM package containing the Active Directory database and SYSVOL. Using ntdsutil via elevated CMD, I navigated to the IFM module and executed the command: create sysvol full C:\ifm This IFM folder allows a new domain controller to be promoted without replicating over the WAN â€” ideal for branch offices.2ï¸âƒ£ Lab Structure and Configuration I designed two sites: Cairo and Mansoura.Cairoâ€™s Server 2016 was configured as a Primary Domain Controller (PDC) and joined with a Windows 10 client in the same domain.The network was fully connected (pingable), and proper domain resolution was ensured through DNS configuration.I added a second Ethernet adapter and implemented NIC Teaming, enhancing bandwidth and redundancy.ğŸ’¡ NIC Teaming Benefits:Increased throughput via load balancingNetwork fault toleranceSeamless connectivity in case of NIC failure3ï¸âƒ£ Cloning and SID Regeneration for New Site To prepare the Mansoura site, I cloned the Cairo server and changed its SID using Sysprep to avoid domain conflicts. Upon reboot, the server was demoted to a Workgroup â€” a critical step in separating domain identity between sites.4ï¸âƒ£ Establishing Trust & Promoting the ADCI reconnected the Mansoura server to the Cairo network.Ensured two-way communication was functional (DNS + pingable).Installed Active Directory Domain Services on Mansoura's server.Promoted it as an Additional Domain Controller (ADC) using credentials from the existing domain (tshoot\administrator).Selected Mansoura as the site and enabled both DNS and Global Catalog roles.5ï¸âƒ£ IFM-Based User Replication Post-promotion, I imported the users from the previously created IFM folder. âœ… Users created in Cairo were instantly visible in Mansoura â€” proving successful replication.6ï¸âƒ£ Final TouchesRenamed servers accordingly: PDC (Cairo) and ADC (Mansoura)Disabled firewalls to avoid blocking replication or communicationInstalled VMware Tools to enhance performance and integrationğŸ’¼ This project was a deep dive into multi-site domain architecture, replication, network optimization, and disaster recovery readiness â€” and honestly, it felt like managing an enterprise-level infrastructure.Always striving to learn by doing, and this one was a milestone.Mohamed Tarek Zyad Waleed Elzyat Ali Khaled hashtag#MCSA hashtag#ActiveDirectory hashtag#Sysadmin hashtag#WindowsServer2016 hashtag#Networking hashtag#ITInfrastructure hashtag#NICTeaming hashtag#InstallFromMedia hashtag#LinkedInLearning hashtag#SysadminLife hashtag#MCSE hashtag#ITProjects

Here is a small useful Rendering Tool I recently worked which makes it easy to Render image sequence in hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana projectKey Features are:1.Render multiple/infinite Render nodes sequentially. you give it all the render nodes in your .katana project file and their frame range, the it will batch render the next render node after the first is finished until all nodes finish rendering. eg: node2 after node1, node3 after node2, node4 after node3 etc, unlimited.2.Render engine independent, works with any Render Engine supported by Katana.3.Katana version independent. works with any katana version, older or newer.4. Threaded Execution (No Freezing UI), tool runs in separate thread to from freezing when rendering5. Render log file for each render node.- Each render node generates a log file in the project directory.- The log file is named: RenderNode_Render_Log_TIMESTAMP.txt- It captures all rendering activity, errors, and messages.6. Shutdown After Render (Checkbox) If enabled shutdown in 60 secs after the last render node finishes rendering. 7. Supports Windows and LinuxNB: Katana Batch Master works on a single workstation.https://lnkd.in/dnySa8fPhashtag#Lightingartist hashtag#Foundry hashtag#Katana8.0 hashtag#Rendering hashtag#Renderman hashtag#USD hashtag#Lookdev hashtag#PipelineTD hashtag#Render

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends
